revisions.rev:
{{Infobox Website | name = Google Images | logo = [[Image:Google Image Search.png|200px|Google Image Search homepage]] | screenshot = | caption = The Google Image Search logo | url = [http://images.google.com/ images.google.com] | commercial = Yes | type = [[Image]] [[Search engine|Search Engine]] | language = [[#International|multilingual]] (~100) | registration = Optional | owner = [[Google|Google Inc.]] | author = Miss Egremont | launch date = July 2001 | current status = Active | revenue = | slogan = | alexa = }}
'''Google Images''' is a [[search engine|search]] service created by [[Google]] that allows users to search the [[World Wide Web|Web]] for [[image]] content. The feature was introduced in July 2001.<ref>Zipern, Andrew. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/12/technology/news-watch-a-quick-way-to-search-for-images-on-the-web.html A Quick Way to Search For Images on the Web]." ''New York Times.'' 12 July 2001. Retrieved 13 September 2009.</ref> The [[Keyword (Internet search)|keywords]] for the image search are based on the filename of the image, the link text pointing to the image, and text adjacent to the image. When searching for an image, a [[thumbnail]] of each matching image is displayed. When the user clicks on a thumbnail, the image is displayed in a box over the website that it came from. The user can then close the box and browse the website, or view the full-sized image.
In early 2007 Google implemented an updated [[user interface]] for the image search, where information about the image, such as resolution and [[Uniform Resource Locator|URL]], was hidden until the user moved the mouse over the thumbnail.<ref>[http://donutey.com/googleimage.php Updated Google Images UI]</ref> This was discontinued after a few weeks.
On July 20, 2010, Google updated the [[user interface]] again, hiding image details until mouse over, like before.<ref> [http://mashable.com/2010/07/20/google-images/ Google Image Search Gets an Overhaul] </ref> This feature can be disabled by pressing "Ctrl + End" on one's keyboard and clicking "Switch to basic version".
On October 27, 2009, Google Images added a feature to its image search that can be used to find similar images.<ref>[http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2009/10/similar-images-graduates-from-google.html Similar Images graduates from Google Labs]</ref><ref>[http://www.cbronline.com/news/google_launches_similar_images_search_tool_281009 Google launches âsimilar imagesâ search tool]</ref><ref>[http://tusharvickkie.blogspot.com/2009/10/new-feature-in-google-image-search-for.html A new feature in Google image search for searching similar images]</ref>
In 2001, 250 million images were indexed. In 2005, this grew to 1 billion. By 2010, the index reached 10 billion images.<ref>[http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/07/ooh-ahh-google-images-presents-nicer.html]</ref> The service gets over one billion [[page view]]s a day, as of July 2010.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-10693439]</ref> Google introduced a sort by subject feature for a visual category scheme overview of a search query in May 2011.<ref name="sort by subject">{{cite web|title=Google Wins the War Against Bing Images|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/227563/google_wins_the_war_against_bing_images.html|publisher=PCWorld Communications, Inc.|accessdate=27 May 2011|author=Eric Mack|date=10|month=May|year=2011}}</ref>
In October of 2011, Google Images began to allow for reverse image searches directly in the image search-bar (that is, without a third-party add on, such as the one previously available for Mozilla Firefox). This feature allows users to search by dragging and dropping an image into the search-bar, uploading an image, selecting a URL, or 'right-clicking' on an image. {{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}<!-- Note: This tag has been before in wrong format, so I corrected the format but added the new date since I don't know month this tag was added. --->
